name: Passionflower
summary: Passionflower (Passiflora incarnata) is a traditional herbal supplement used for anxiety, insomnia, and stress relief, with mild sedative and anxiolytic properties.
description: Passionflower is an herbal remedy derived from Passiflora incarnata, historically used in European and Native American medicine for nervous restlessness, anxiety, and sleep disturbances. Its compounds, including flavonoids and alkaloids, are thought to modulate GABAergic neurotransmission, producing calming effects similar to benzodiazepines but generally milder. Modern clinical evidence suggests possible benefits in generalized anxiety disorder, adjustment disorder, and sleep initiation, though high-quality trials remain limited. It is often used as a gentler alternative to prescription sedatives.

metadata.natural_source: Leaves, stems, and flowers of Passiflora incarnata
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

off_label_uses: Adjunctive support in generalized anxiety disorder

items: Supports relaxation and reduces nervous restlessness
May reduce symptoms of mild anxiety

sections.text: Passionflower extracts are thought to enhance GABAergic signaling in the brain, increasing inhibitory neurotransmission and producing calming, anxiolytic, and sedative effects. Flavonoids such as chrysin may contribute to this activity.

adult.typical: 250–500 mg standardized extract up to 3 times daily, or tea infusion (2 g dried herb steeped 10–15 minutes, 2–3 times daily).
adult.note: Often used in the evening for sleep support.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended; limited safety data.

sections.text: Sedative and calming effects may be noticeable within 30–60 minutes; benefits for sleep and anxiety may accumulate over several days of use.

serious: Excessive sedation when combined with other CNS depressants

other: Avoid in pregnancy due to potential uterine stimulation.
May potentiate sedative medications including benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and antihistamines.

sections.pregnancy: Avoid due to uterine stimulation risk
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; avoid routine use
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe at low doses; monitor for fall risk due to sedation

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal, though abrupt cessation after long use could lead to return of symptoms.

items: Commonly combined with other calming herbs such as valerian or lemon balm in sleep and anxiety formulations.
Milder effect compared to prescription anxiolytics, but well tolerated for short-term use.
Evidence base is limited; best for mild cases or adjunctive therapy.
